job_title: Evs- Housekeeper in Las Vegas, NV
pros: They have good programs like appreciation days or holidays where we all get buffets. They have good insurance for their employees, the pay is not bad. Once the nurses get to know you after a couple months they eventually stop hazing you, some areas are better than others.
cons: Get less than a quarter raises every year, which is really sad. Nurses are always challenging, I'm not saying there aren't any good ones but for people who have a career in helping others I have never been treated so bad or bullied so much. They treat you as though you are nothing because you clean there. Although I feel they should feel fortunate enough to have someone clean everything for them where other hospitals aren't that lucky in which the nurses have to clean up. But the more you give them the more they want. They are definitely the priority for the hospital, so if you are a nurse this is the perfect place for you to work.

job_title: Staff RN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: It is a perfect place to learn and established your fundamentals, the doctors were approachable and eager to share their knowledge, other healthcare disciplines were very friendly.
cons: A little behind in terms of latest medical technology but I know they’re working on it and making changes.

job_title: Clinical Worker in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Good benefits, job security, location is prime,
cons:
I have worked at the hospital for 10+ years and have seen the employee moral decline with the current COO. The positive vibe of the company is no more. They used to reward good behavior for things like finishing mandatory testing, being a good employee. We used to have employee of the month in our department and that devolved away about three years ago. I feel they try to micro manage every aspect of your job. Like where you park. Employees are given 2 levels of a parking garage that is heavily used by patients and visitors. And the "backup" garage is on the opposite side of the hospital from the employee entrance. Let's not even get into the daily car vandalism that occurs there. It has been going on for years and they refuse to beef up security. Rather, they tell employees to take everything out of your car. Things like your registration, garage door openers. Things they know the person committing such vandalism are targeting. There is no room for climbing up the ladder. No cross training. They have an "incident" reporting software that every employee has access to. They say it is for them to improve errors that occur. But the only thing I have seen is write ups for whomever is lower on the totem pole. 
The moral of the place has plummeted to a new low.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros: This was a steady job for years with a nice staff. Mist things were convenient.
cons: My department lacked employees leading me to do more work than I believe my pay sufficed.

job_title: Registration in Las Vegas, NV
pros: The majority of co-workers are very nice and I actually do like my manager.
cons:
- Always, always, always understaffed.  
- On-Call/Per-diem folk are not used properly.  I mean if it's a real busy day CALL THEM IN.  The fact that management is so restricted with hours in a registration department that makes over 300,000 a month in collections for the hospital is ridiculous.
- Employees that slack off and don't care about the rest of the team kind of ease on by.
- The work load can be a bit ridiculous especially working in the ER.
- Patients constantly complain regarding the amount of papers they have to sign.  I mean seriously...why should an ER patient have to sign almost 20 pages worth of documents?  It's ridiculous.
- It's all about the collections.  Customer service is very secondary.
- No real part-time positions are available.  It's all full-time or per-diem.  The CEO has no tolerance for more than 3 per-diems for a staff of 30.  And refuses to give us a part-time person on the weekend...which are normally are busiest days...even though we are already more understaffed on the weekend than on the weekdays.  
-WAY underpaid for how much they expect of you.  

Just stay away.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
Almost always available OT. 
Flexible schedule. 
Ability to work at any of the hospitals within the system.
cons:
RN ratios 7:1
CNA ratios 18:1
Low wages. 
High turn over. 
Clique-like environment across different departments. 
Ability to make a change in the company is non-existent. 
Opportunity for advancement is non-existent unless you’re going through the nursing pathway. 
Committees that serve as figure heads with no real purpose or function. 
Machines pertinent to providing quality care are broken/do not work (VS machines/WOW’s)

review_title: Exhausting and treated like dirt on shoe.

job_title: RN Staff in Las Vegas, NV
pros: UHS implements evidenced based practices and best practices and supplies were more cutting edge. There was outstanding educational support for newly hired nurses within the UHS System.
cons:
This hospital is far from pro-nursing. I last worked there in 2010 and at that time there was no strive for Magnet status. This may have changed since this credential is now highly associated with Quality care and the embodiment of Health Reform is looking closely at quality. As I stated above there was excellent educational support for new nurses but, it seemed to stop there rather than encouraging all of their nursing staff through various stages of there careers. 
I was a critical care nurse in the MICU and last worked at Summerlin Medical Center in 12/2010 at that time the nursing culture in the MICU did not embrace the nursing profession rather than seeing it as a job. There were literally 2 strong nursing leaders during the time that I worked at Summerlin MICU and a crew of punitive management (most charge nurses included) which were not leaders. 
Lastly there were no intensivists in the critical care units or house doctors for the floors to support patients and nurses overnight or even in a critical situation.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Everyone from staff to administrators strives to provide excellent patient care. While we're not perfect, we try to improve on a daily basis. I have wonderful coworkers who usually work well as a team.
cons: Because it is part of a for-profit, larger corporate structure; change sometimes is slow to happen and they forget that in business; sometimes you have to spend a little money to make money!

review_title: Great place. Some of senior leadership is great. Engagement team is doing more. HR is more  visible.

review_title: Should be closed for renovation and  deep cleaning.
job_title: Staff RN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Good benefits. Less homeless patients.
cons: No extra shifts.  Asked to float all the time. One CNA per floor!  Dirty place. Old beat up equipment. Tiny patient's rooms with broken recliners and restrooms not equipped to prevent  falls. Lack of computers  and wheeled computer stations to chart. Very noisy and crowded nursing stations. Tiny dark closet-like  medroom for one person fit  with no counter space. Too many nursing students per one unit.    RN serves food trays. Slow old  Citrix  program often does't work.

review_title: Staff in higher position treat other unfairly.
job_title: Hospital Worker in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great insurance. The job is not hard. Holiday pay is good.
cons: Too much favoritism. An employee harassed and bullied other employees only to be put on a different shift. This employee is now doing the exact same thing on that shift! He is a great politician who sweet talks people in high positions and they buy into all his lies! He loves to brag about the people he knows in high places and how that’s how he’s been able to do what he wants when he wants. He even lets his favorite employees hang out in his office and slack off while he gets other employees to pick up the slack. Human Resources has let him get away with this for years.  An employee in a high position from this hospital is so fake.  Many staff members have stated they have said hello to this person and the person will look you straight in the eye and won’t respond or acknowledge you. This employee is suppose to set an example! Nurses treat evs workers like the lowest of low. They expect them to do everything and won’t even say hello or give you a simple thank you for helping them out at times. Cafeteria workers, floor workers and evs all get treated this way by nurses, doctors and even some pharmacy employees. We work just as hard if not more than they do to be treated as if we are lower than dirt.  Going to Human Resources about an employee is pointless because that person just gets moved to a different position.  People in higher places will say they will work on it or fix it, but things don’t change.
